_header: Miseremini mei ye that been my friends
Note:
Four lines apparently adapted from st. 1, lines 1-3, appear beneath the Latin epitaph of Thomas Dalby, Archdeacon of Richmond, d. 26 Jan. 1526, in north aisle of choir in York Minster, pr. Leach (1903)
XLeach, Arthur Francis. Memorials of Beverly Minster. The Chapter Act Book of the Collegiate Church of S. John of Beverley A. D. 1286-1347. Vol. 2.
Surtees Society 108 (1903), xcv.
Subjects: Edward IV, lamentation of soul of; laments
_description: The lamentation of the soul of Edward IV, attributed to Skelton — in 12-line stanzas (ababcdcdefef) with refrain, ‘Ecce nunc in puluere dormio’

BLHar4011.First Lines:
Miseremini mei ye that ben my ffryndysThis world hath enformyd me
                    fforto fall…
BLHar4011.Last Lines:
…As I forsayd youre kyng I wasEt ecce nunc in puluere
                    dormio
BLHar4011.Editions:
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild,
                        ed.  
             Religious Lyrics of the XVth Century.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1939: 250-3.

BLAdd29729.First Lines:
Miseremini mei ye that be my fryndysthe worlde hathe informed me
                    for to fawlle…
BLAdd29729.Last Lines:
…As ferst sayd yowr kynge I wasEt ecce nunc in pulvere
                    dormio
BLAdd29729.Attributed Title:
here folowythe the Epitaphy of Kynge Edward þe fowrthe complyd
                        [sic] by Iohn lidgate monke of burye
Skelton (f. 8, as heading all by scribe—John
                    Stow—including crossing through and substituting ‘Skelton’);
                    ‘Explicit þe Epitaffe of Kynge edward the fowrthe made by Iohn
                    lidgate monke of bery skelton’ (f. 9r below last line all by scribe (John
                    Stow) including crossing through and substituting ‘Skelton')

Corning6.First Lines:
[M]iserere mei ȝe þat be my frendisfor þe
                    world haþe enformid me to fall…
Corning6.Last Lines:
…As I arst seyd ȝour kyng I wasEt Ecce nunc in puluere
                        dormio
Corning6.Attributed Title: Explicit A lamentable of kyng Edward þe iiii (f. 132)
